episodes.description: Learning a the fundamentals of programming is very empowering, but the next question is how can I use it? We are going to use some of the skills and knowledge that you have acquired to build a childhood game, Hangman, on in the command line environment. Let's get started!
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.941
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:04.918 --> 00:00:08.220
Hello everyone, and
welcome to this course overview for

3
00:00:08.220 --> 00:00:10.360
Applied Fundamentals at DevProTV.

4
00:00:10.360 --> 00:00:13.840
And here to help us is Mr.
Justin Dennison.

5
00:00:13.840 --> 00:00:16.410
So Justin, tell me what are we
gonna be learning in this

6
00:00:16.410 --> 00:00:17.180
series?
>> Well,

7
00:00:17.180 --> 00:00:19.900
this series is actually
a culmination of some of these

8
00:00:19.900 --> 00:00:23.420
introductory skills that we've been
learning over the last few courses.

9
00:00:23.420 --> 00:00:26.990
So if you're here, there's an assumption
you've learned some Python,

10
00:00:26.990 --> 00:00:29.960
you've learned some
concepts about programming.

11
00:00:29.960 --> 00:00:31.910
And now, we're here to flex those muscles.

12
00:00:31.910 --> 00:00:33.180
And in order to do that,

13
00:00:33.180 --> 00:00:37.240
we're gonna apply the problem solving
skills that we also learned about.

14
00:00:37.240 --> 00:00:39.780
To plan our project, draw pictures,

15
00:00:39.780 --> 00:00:43.850
make sure that we understand the dynamics
of what we're trying to build.

16
00:00:43.850 --> 00:00:45.980
And then,
utilize the programming concepts.

17
00:00:45.980 --> 00:00:51.110
Like functions, and strings, and
methods, and also loops, in order to

18
00:00:51.110 --> 00:00:56.681
actually build the Hangman game, which
I find is always a a childhood classic.

19
00:00:56.681 --> 00:01:00.200
But sometimes it's a little macabre,
so maybe we'll have to change that

20
00:01:00.200 --> 00:01:02.790
in of itself.
>> All right, well you mentioned

21
00:01:02.790 --> 00:01:05.950
you might have watched a few episodes,
you have a kind of base knowledge.

22
00:01:05.950 --> 00:01:08.620
But who's the intended audience?

23
00:01:08.620 --> 00:01:12.150
Do we need to have these prerequisites
that you maybe have mentioned

24
00:01:12.150 --> 00:01:14.690
to watch this series?
>> I think having the prerequisites,

25
00:01:14.690 --> 00:01:17.310
watching the courses
about problem-solving,

26
00:01:17.310 --> 00:01:21.470
about introduction to programming, about
getting comfortable with the terminal,

27
00:01:21.470 --> 00:01:25.090
as well how to define and
think about functions.

28
00:01:25.090 --> 00:01:28.910
Those, you might get away
with not knowing those.

29
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:32.640
But it's going to make a lot
more sense and also help cement

30
00:01:32.640 --> 00:01:36.150
what you've learned in those previous
courses as you build this project.

31
00:01:36.150 --> 00:01:38.250
So it's highly recommended.

32
00:01:38.250 --> 00:01:41.693
You might get away with not having them,
but for me,

33
00:01:41.693 --> 00:01:46.041
I would recommend them strongly.
>> Okay, is this series directed towards

34
00:01:46.041 --> 00:01:50.370
any type of specific certification, or is
this more of just a general knowledge to

35
00:01:50.370 --> 00:01:54.130
help us better coders?
>> This is an application of

36
00:01:54.130 --> 00:01:57.410
some of the beginning things that you
learn when you start programming, right?

37
00:01:57.410 --> 00:02:00.480
So what is an a list, and how do I use it?

38
00:02:00.480 --> 00:02:02.376
What is a string, and how do I use it?

39
00:02:02.376 --> 00:02:04.450
What is a function, how do I use it?

40
00:02:04.450 --> 00:02:07.454
What are the patterns of thought
that I need to employ in order to

41
00:02:07.454 --> 00:02:08.370
build something?

42
00:02:08.370 --> 00:02:12.110
Because they're kind of odd
to put all those together.

43
00:02:12.110 --> 00:02:15.790
Now, that is not a certification,
that'd be really hard to certify in.

44
00:02:15.790 --> 00:02:20.390
So this is about leveling up your skills
and making sure that you understand

45
00:02:20.390 --> 00:02:24.200
the fundamentals of, well,
of programing in and of itself.

46
00:02:24.200 --> 00:02:26.995
So if that sounds like something that
you're excited about, I hope you are,

47
00:02:26.995 --> 00:02:27.989
then we'll see you there.

48
00:02:27.989 --> 00:02:35.663
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne think through creating our first project, Hangman. Justin spends some time to demonstrate the thought processes when planning a project.
episodes.title: Plan The Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne spend some time getting the project structure created. Additionally, they discuss the reason for the decisions that are made and what are some alternatives.
episodes.title: Set Up The Project

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne start creating the Hangman application. First step, allow the player to enter guesses on a continuous basis.
episodes.title: Take Guesses

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne further expand on the game to determine if the user's guess is correct or not.
episodes.title: Determine Correct Guesses

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore had to provide a nicer interface to the game. Justin provides a look at the thought process about the organization of the game as well as how he decided what the user interface should look like.
episodes.title: Add Presentation

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore a little bit of clean up. The first step of building the game was getting it to work, which is finished. However, the project is a little messy and before moving forward with more features, Justin shows how to extract portions into functions to improve readability.
episodes.title: Refactor to Functions

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne explore how to add a scoreboard to keep track of the number of incorrect guesses.
episodes.title: Add a Scoreboard

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne alter the logic of the game to now have a win or lose condition instead of an automatic win.
episodes.title: Determine Win or Lose

episodes.description: In this episode, Justin and Vonne add more dramatic portions to the interface when a player loses or wins.
episodes.title: Print Banners
